body: As has become increasingly clear in recent years, great dining in New York City isn't limited to Manhattan. The Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island all offer their share of interesting restaurants. Here are eight: AESOP'S TABLES * [Rating: one star] (718) 720-2005; 1233 Bay Street (Maryland Avenue); Rosebank, Staten Island; $$; Review:
title: GOOD EATING; Dine Out (of Manhattan)

body: In a city of lines, some of the longest are now for health insurance. By 6 a.m. in Brooklyn, they form outside the Bushwick Medicaid office. And at the Boerum Hill center, they sometimes snake around the block. At Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan, they stretch down the hall. The need for health coverage is a vexing old problem that has become
title: Disaster Gives The Uninsured Wider Access To Medicaid

body: HOW often is it that a New Yorker gets a chance to work in a charming old building that looks like a medieval fortress, and from an office window, can hear sea lions barking for their chow three times a day? David Rivel is in this fanciful situation. He's the new executive director of the City Parks Foundation, a nonprofit group that raises money
title: PUBLIC LIVES; From a Room With a View, Going to Bat for Parks

body: When a group of building-preservation experts met recently to discuss how the attack on the World Trade Center had affected nearby landmarks, among those who paid particularly close attention was a curriculum developer for a new Brooklyn high school. Kate Burns Ottavino listened intently to a discussion on the composition of the ash that is coating
title: A Curriculum Bent by the Prism of Preservation

body: NEW YORK is forever disappearing. We live amid many lost cities: F. Scott Fitzgerald's glittering, white boomtown. E. B. White's hot, haunting August of 1948. The small society of the midcentury eccentric Joe Gould. Dan Wakefield's Greenwich Village of the 50's. There's also that perennial vision of a livable place with quiet museum galleries and
title: URBAN TACTICS; A Lost City, Reborn for Now

body: ATLANTIC AVENUE in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn is a new destination for moderately priced modern furniture, lighting and rugs as well as antiques. If you are going to the Brooklyn Museum of Art's new show, ''Vital Forms: American Art and Design in the Atomic Age, 1940-1960,'' Atlantic Avenue is a worthwhile detour. 1. Foundation has a
title: PERSONAL SHOPPER: BOERUM HILL; A New Beachhead for Modern Design

author: Jonathan Lethem is the author of the novel ''Motherless Brooklyn.''
body: 1.It began for me here, in the same room where I sit now, in Boerum Hill. It began as a non sequitur crackle of sunlight thunder, on a gorgeous morning after an evening of thunderstorms. I ignored the sound, took a shower instead, wondering about the sports page: had Roger Clemens won his 20th? The phone rang, and a friend asked: ''Did you see
title: 9 Failures of The Imagination

body: The news conference yesterday seemed pretty straightforward. Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, stood at a Boerum Hill housing project, telling reporters that his office had just won indictments of 13 gang members on murder and drug charges. But as Mr. Hynes announced that the gang had terrorized the neighborhood for years, some
title: Hynes Greeted With Questions On Harassment

body: The City Planning Commission has established a Downtown Brooklyn Special District. Delineating a downtown area where buildings up to 495 feet would be allowed and commercial activity encouraged, the commission imposed 60-to-120-foot height restrictions on new buildings in the adjacent areas of Brooklyn Heights and Boerum Hill. ''When viewed in the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPDATES; BROOKLYN HEIGHTS

body: The city announced a series of traffic changes for Downtown Brooklyn yesterday, all intended to make crossing the street a less harrowing experience in an area where a commercial revival has brought a huge increase in traffic that often spills over onto residential sidestreets. The dozen or so modifications, which include wider sidewalks at
title: Traffic Test Planned for Harried Downtown Brooklyn

body: Sites chosen for the National Register of Historic Places are usually either architectural wonders or otherwise undistinguished places touched by famous lives. But a group of places without any such traits, including four from New York, have recently made the list. They are spots where immigrants or other unsung Americans gathered for decades to
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Landmarks of Joy, Music, Friendship and Devotion

body: SMITH STREET, Brooklyn's restaurant row, has been called the hottest new hot spot in New York. Newspapers and magazines have been filled with articles about the street in Boerum Hill, as if the strip had sat there its whole life gathering dust until the young and hip arrived a few years ago and put the place on the map. Truth be told, the 14-block
title: CITY LORE; Smith St.: A Hot Strip With a Storied Past

body: When the long-troubled John Jay High School in Park Slope, Brooklyn, closed its doors for good a week ago today, the goodbyes were tinged with a mix of emotions. Some students and teachers at the academically struggling school said they believed that they were being forced out by middle-class neighborhood parents looking for a new school for their
title: Reinventing John Jay High Amid Charges of Exclusion

body: IF Yamani Sekhri, who received her M.B.A. from Indiana University in May, had been searching for an apartment in Manhattan a year ago, Michael Shapot would have had one listing, maybe two, to show her on any given day. But this year is different. Ms. Sekhri, who began as an investment banking associate with UBS Warburg in May, phoned Mr. Shapot, an
title: For Class of 2001, a Less Frenetic Market

body: Some Old Standards Dishes that might be clichés suit the setting at 92, Ken Aretsky's new place at 45 East 92nd Street. The restaurant is slightly retro-looking, with booths and tables in a burgundy color scheme. The full menu, available starting on Friday, includes grilled chicken Caesar salad, meatloaf, soft-shell crabs, and iceberg lettuce and
title: OFF THE MENU

body: A FAMILIAR green image of a mermaid stands on Van Brunt Street in Red Hook, Brooklyn, near the corner of Coffey Street. ''Coming Soon,'' the sign says, ''Starbucks Coffey.'' Both a play on words and a joking reference to the neighborhood's nascent gentrification, the sign does not seem an accurate prediction -- at least not yet. With a long history
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Red Hook; Isolated Brooklyn Area Starts to Awaken

body: Like most people who spend their days on the banks of the Gowanus Canal, a two-mile stretch of water that starts at the mouth of New York Harbor and dead-ends in South Brooklyn, Dan Kinney used to run for cover when barges came through, kicking up the putrid refuse that had settled on the bottom. ''Run for the nearest building and close the door!''
title: Once a Mess, Canal Aspires To Beauty Now

body: Four men were convicted yesterday of conspiring with Osama bin Laden in a terrorist plot to bomb the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in 1998. The blasts killed 224 people, injured thousands and glaringly exposed the United States' vulnerability abroad. Two of the defendants were also found guilty of murder and could now face execution.
title: THE TERROR VERDICT: THE OVERVIEW; 4 GUILTY IN TERROR BOMBINGS OF 2 U.S. EMBASSIES IN AFRICA; JURY TO WEIGH 2 EXECUTIONS

body: As a prominent New York architect and the dean of the Yale School of Architecture, Robert A. M. Stern is known for designing dream mansions on Long Island, a modern classical office tower in Boston, and a whimsical Disney building in Burbank, Calif. Less well known is his connection with Brooklyn Law School, for which Mr. Stern, a Brooklyn native
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; A Native Son to Design for the Law School

body: To the Editor: About the naming of Cobble Hill in Brooklyn [''A Landmark Area With a Family Bent,'' May 6] ''by a real estate agent who sought to increase the market potential of the brownstone-lined streets.'': According to a local journalist quoted in the article, ''Everyone has forgotten who that person was.'' Not everyone. It was Sori Kuralt,
title: The Mystery Of Cobble Hill

body: THE name conjures up images of peaceful 19th-century residential streets, which in many ways are still present. But the only cobblestones near the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn -- one of the oldest residential neighborhoods in the borough -- can be found in a largely industrial area just west of the neighborhood on a street named Tiffany Place.
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Cobble Hill; A Landmark Area With a Family Bent

Inside, parishioners banged tambourines against their palms and hit
title: Making Spirits Rock From Church to Clubland; A Gospel Pedal Steel Guitarist Dives Into Pop

''It was the highest price ever paid for a co-op in the Heights,'' said Christopher Thomas, vice
title: Across the City, A Strong Market

title: SPARE TIMES; FOR CHILDREN

body: The paychecks come on Thursday. When the walking boss calls quitting time, the ironworkers stuff their tool belts into empty bolt buckets and stash them near the columns. They cram themselves into the freight elevator and someone is wearing cologne. They descend to the dressing shacks and change into their street clothes. Some go to the banks and
title: A Mohawk Trail To the Skyline; Indian Ironworkers Return, Lured by Building Boom

body: NEW YORK MINEOLA: 'SAFE HAVEN' HOSPITALS -- Denis Dillon, the Nassau County district attorney, designated four hospitals as safe havens yesterday under a new state law allowing parents to leave newborns at specific hospitals around the county as an alternative to abandonment or worse. The hospitals are Nassau University Medical Center, East Meadow;
title: METRO BRIEFING

body: At Smith's Bar on 44th Street and Eighth Avenue on Tuesday night, the ironworkers were talking of little else. It had rained that morning, and then the rain turned to a light snow. A young steel connecter working in Midtown tried an old ironworker's trick: sliding down a column head first. He slipped, did a flip in the air and landed two floors
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENDING ELBOWS; Iron in the Blood, Misfortune on the Mind

body: AMONG the French bistros that dominate the Smith Street restaurant row in Brooklyn, Smith Street Kitchen alone specializes in seafood. And perhaps best of all, the restaurant offers excellent value, especially now, when prices have risen and few fish restaurants are accessible to diners on a moderate budget. With its worn velvet banquettes,
title: $25 AND UNDER; In Brooklyn, a Bistro Comes Into Its Own

body: A chart on Jan. 28 outlining the history of St. Nicholas Antiochan Orthodox Cathedral in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, mislabeled the period in which Arabic-speaking Orthodox Christians formed an association and opened a church in Manhattan. It was the 1890's, not the 1980's.
title: Corrections

body: A Brooklyn man who had worked for the City Council for more than a decade was fatally shot by a group of men trying to rob his apartment late Monday afternoon, the police said. The man, Charles Woods, 29, who lived in the Gowanus Houses in Boerum Hill, worked as a clerk in the Council Services Department, which orders supplies and equipment for
title: City Council Worker Killed In Robbery Attempt at Home

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; No Parking, No Parishioners, an Orthodox Church Fears

body: ON a recent winter afternoon, as the temperature dipped below freezing and a brisk wind blew along the cross streets of Midtown Manhattan, an ironworker named John Collins stepped out onto a six-inch-wide steel beam 24 stories above Seventh Avenue and started to walk across it. Mr. Collins carried 45 pounds of equipment on his belt, including two
title: Cowboys of the Sky

body: In a legal settlement announced yesterday by a coalition of neighborhood groups in Brooklyn, state and federal transportation agencies that are planning to rebuild the Gowanus Expressway have agreed to work closely with a committee of residents and elective officials. The Brooklyn groups have long favored replacing the decrepit 5.7-mile stretch of
title: Neighbors Will Have Voice In Gowanus Road Project

body: NEW YORK BROOKLYN: HOLTZMAN ROBBED -- Elizabeth Holtzman, the former Brooklyn district attorney, was robbed in front of her home in Boerum Hill on Tuesday as she left a taxi, the police said yesterday. Ms. Holtzman, 59, told the police that as she approached the gate to her brownstone she was confronted by a man with a silver-colored gun who
title: METRO BRIEFING

body: An Internet Entree With Beverages Joining the multitude of communications centers in Times Square is an Internet cafe, EasyEverything, with 800 computers at 234 42nd Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. EasyEverything is the first American venture for the London-based EasyGroup, which operates Internet cafes in Europe. The price of access
title: IN BRIEF

body: Ask children, and they'll probably tell you that the best material for patching things up is cookie dough. Not literally, of course, but youngsters seem to know that mending fences -- the metaphorical kind -- goes more easily when you invite people to share something sweet. That's the cheery premise of ''The Little House of Cookies,'' the latest
title: FAMILY FARE; For Problems, Sweet Solutions
